columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about intuition and the option's value.

To start with, let us define an option. 

**Options** are types of financial contracts which give the holder the right, but not the obligation to buy or sell a specific asset at a predetermined price, on or before its date of expiration.

Here are the parameters to solve the problem: 

|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Current stock price |$63 | 
| Risk-free rate (r)|5% | 
|Possible stock price in one year |$70 or $80 |

We are asked to solve the value of the call option with an exercise price of $70. 

The value of the option is solved as follows: 

$$\textbf{Value of Option}=\frac{\text{CV of Stock}}{\left(1+\text{r}\right)}$$

Where: 

- CV - Current Value


The current value of a stock is divided by the sum of 1 and risk-free rate to determine the value of option.

Whereas the current value of the stock is solved as follows:

$$\textbf{Current Value}=\text{Stock Price}-\text{Exercise Price}$$

The exercise price is deducted from the possible stock price to determine the current value of the stock.

Using the equation in Step 5,  let us solve the current value of the stock if the stock price is $70:

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current Value}&=\$70-\$70\\[15pt]
&=0
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the current value of the option is zero if the stock price is $70 at the end of the year.

Now, let us solve the current value of the stock if the stock price is $80:

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current Value}&=\$80-\$70\\[15pt]
&=\$10
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the current value of the option is $10 if the stock price is $80 at the end of the year.

Now, let us solve the current value if the probability of $70 and $80 stock price is equally likely at the end of the year. 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current Value}&=\left(0\times0.50\right)+\left(\$10\times0.50\right)\\[15pt]
&=0+\$5\\[15pt]
&=\$5
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the current value of the option is $5.
